intro: Chaerophyllum colensoi var. hispidum, commonly known as the hairy chaerophyllum, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are clustered in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, shady environments and is often found in forest understories. Its hairy texture and unique appearance make it a distinctive and ecologically important species in its native habitat.
